App description: Create amazing street art with VR. Sharpen your skills or learn new styles with thousands of online artists from around the world. Up to 4 simultaneous players collaborating at once. Customize your in game avatar by designing your own hat, mask and spray can. Use True to life Ironlak Aerosol colours to design and develop skills and bring your concepts closer to reality. Feel immersed in 12 realistic environments including a trainyard, Alleyway, dusky city rooftop, and an abandoned subway station! This is just a fraction of the awesomeness you will find in Kingspray. Can't WAIT to see what you make!

saltysixJul 14 at 6:08 PM
Excellent, looking forward to more!

Extremely creative, immersive environment for graffiti artistry, for newcomers and advanced users alike. Intuitive play, good physics, excellent environments. Has not been updated though in a long time, feels abandoned, missing out on very important social components and overall potential as a result. Highly recommended regardless though, very good although socially isolated in its current form. Recommended updates: In game tutorials, perhaps in the form of templates and narration, would be extremely helpful to newcomers. Also, I don't see a way to export work from the game to social media or email, GDrive, etc. The website did not appear to import the work I created, so for now it seems as though sharing your work with the world is a bit difficult (and I apologize if I'm missing something). Would like to see this. Would also be helpful to allow DIY images like sketch jpgs, etc. to be brought in as project reference (as photos on the in-game phone would be good, or even superimposed on walls; although this would reduce realism, it would be great for practice). I found myself taking off the Oculus frequently to check against my external design concept. Third party radio stations and/or Spotify playlists, and an in-game real-world clock to keep an eye on the time would be great. Game elements would be welcome as well, such as objectives (contract work by NPCs to earn currency to open secret areas, etc.).

Devs please make game cross platform

To all the guys and girls at Infectious Ape,

This app is awesome on Oculus Rift, if it had a few more larger multiplayer oriented painting spaces then it would be GOLDEN. HOWEVER, on the Oculus Quest I find it to be severely lacking. Which is why Im rating it 4 stars.

1) Mainly, the paint mechanics are nowhere near as good as on the rift. The fades come out splotchy no matter what distance, pressure, or trigger pressure that is used. The standard cap is the only cap with good fade. On the rift the painting mechanics felt very on point, fading was smooth and trigger sensitivity was excellent.
2) Its missing many of the awesome features that were added to the Rift like ladders/lifts and an undo button
3) Multiplayer with Rift users is impossible!! This was the whole reason I bought a quest. I thought I would be able to paint with crew mates that are far away.

Devs, Ive been painting graffiti for going on ten years, and this app has SO MUCH POTENTIAL! Please dont abandon it! I would be willing to pay more for the app if these things could be addressed, ESPECIALLY the Quest paint mechanics. Please feel free to contact me if more elaboration is needed!

siamese605Oct 22 at 9:01 AM
Graffiti Artist since 1992..

I took a couple of days to really soak in this app so I could give honest feedback about it. I started painting graffiti in 1992, so I would consider myself someone who can spot issues with the simulation.
..My honest opinion is that this app is far better than it has any business being. I've played with a couple other true Graffiti artists on there, and at many points we found ourselves geeking out about the accuracy of a certain thing here and there, from the tracking control, to the flares (a style of tag involving wrist movement to manipulate the width and spray of the can), to the lighting and shadowing of the environments, to the pressure sensitivity when holding down the cap (this is finicky in real life, so the fact that it feels natural in the simulation is a miracle.)
I find that the same quirks and deficiencies I have painting on a wall in reality that I have to work around end up organically translate to my experience painting in the game, which is something that can only be achieved by a nearly perfect simulation of the experience.. Even the social experience is eerily similar. The emotions and interactions you go through painting a legal wall feel the same as painting a spot here.
So as far as painting practice, yes, it is that closely aligned and achievable. I remember another artist from Denver saying to me ", think of how good these kids are going to be and how much quicker they will advance because of this!".
Yes, you could develop some bad habits that could mess you up on a wall a bit too if you get lazy, but overall, it is definitely a great and accurate way to develop your skills, and it's extremely addicting. Basically a perfect experience.

This is the game that convinced me buying a Quest was worth it. Its hard to explain what makes the atmosphere so perfect. hargisssOct 17 at 12:55 PM
A great visual art app for Quest

The visual art apps for quest are my favorites. There's Sculptr, Tiltbrush, maybe Gravity Sketch... that was just about it, until now. All those apps are 3D, so I jumped on the chance to do some 2D painting on quest... and it's great! The experience feels highly interactive, as there are many degrees of freedom... moving the spray can closer to the wall makes the stroke smaller, backing away changes the texture, squeezing the trigger different amounts gives you different intensity, and spraying at an angle changes the shape. Every now and then the paint drips for realism. The app runs great, and loads reasonably fast.
Also speaking as someone who has never actually held a can of spray paint, this app is a great look into a world I've had little firsthand experience with. Now when I see graffiti I'll have a better idea of the methods the artists had to use to achieve the effects they did.

MickmanNov 29 at 11:56 AM
The Good the Bad and The UGLY

GOOD-
high level of articulation in terms of flow, paint dispersal and general feel of each cap ie. Fat CaP vs a Thin Cap.

Hardness
When spraying a line, the edges can be very hard (e.g. with a Universal cap on ironlak), or they can fade out and look fuzzy. There are a couple of Softcaps.

Caps that produce hard lines are good for outlining. For hazes and shadings, softer caps are generally preferred.
Size:
Spraying from the same distance with a NY Thin and a NY Fat will result in a much wider dot for the NY Fat. This also defines the minimum width of a line.
Caps which produce wide dots are called Fat Caps.
Reaction time
The Skinny Pro does in fact respond rapidly: When you stop spraying, the paint stops flowing. This does not necessarily need to be the case;
Dot pattern
The dot pattern is the pattern that is produced when spraying on a single point from medium distance.
Consistency
Or Quality. Every cap will produce a slightly different pattern. Consistency is important if you rely on the pattern, e.g. for visual effects & being a digital application its always consistent.. There's no change in temperature or have to deal with enviro. concerns or cops for that matter ;)

THE BAD - No ability to import your own sketches you create in pre-production. It really sux having to take of the VR headset just to view your sketch.
No ability to paint wall corners... all walls a flat. I'd like to have the ability to try out foreshortening, and more 3D designs ie. wrap around corner walls or paint a side walk. It's all flat land I'm afraid.
No ability to Put down a quick base canvas... using a roller.
The lobby area ( called "The Bunker" ) is lack luster in terms of interaction. There's a DJ console but no ability to spin some vinyl... There's a few assets lying around the bunker that have no purpose.
Limited navigation areas. Would be better to move across the street onto other roof tops etc..

The Ugly -
My art still sux ;)

Developer ResponseNov 11 at 4:07 PM

That shouldn't be happening. One thing that catches people off guard sometimes is that you can only see your saved work when you are in the level that you saved it in. For example, if you were working in the underpass and saved a piece using the phone, you'd only see that piece in the "Load" screen of the in game phone if you were in the Underpass while looking at the menu. And if you look at the "Load" menu on the phone while in the Bunker, you'll only see pieces that were saved in the bunker. Right after you take a picture with the phone, go to the load menu and make sure you see the preview of the picture you just took. If not, could it be that your device is running out of space? If you're still having troubles, hop on the discord and we'll help you to get it going (https://discord.gg/Yc2B5av).

rabidredratNov 3 at 2:20 PM
Outstanding

Not sure I can call it a game its a highly responsive graffiti simulator. Very realistic and functional.
From the welcoming screen you can go in to solo mode and choose your wall. You teleport to your required position and start getting creative with the range of different spray cans. All feels very realistic, there is a music selection of cool tunes to paint to and sound great through the quest.
Very easy and happy to lose hours as time flies inside this quest experience.
Save your work by taking a picture of it.
If you don't like what you done you can wash the wall clean and start fresh.
Please note as of yet there is not back function(like real life) so any paint put on the walls sticks and you need to be careful with any mistakes made. Start with a background colour instead of fresh wall is a helpful tip for this.
There's an online experience where you can work on projects together with other players and meet other taggers. Some very talented people out there who share there knowledge.
Thoroughly enjoyable and although I've never tagged a wall in my life I think I'll be great at it with my VR graffiti skills.
You'll save 1000s in real paint, avoid a criminal record, not suffocate on spray fumes and still improve your skills.

When first picking it up it took me a while to get use to the controls, what buttons did what, moving round the space etc. After about 30 mins though i found myself totally immersed within the game. I think the solution to your first issue is teleporting. To activate the teleport laser, hold down the "A" button (or "X" if you are in left-hand mode). That will give you a sort of laser pointer. Point that at the wall or ground and you should see a circle appear on the ground. When you release the teleport button, you will be transported to that spot. That's the quickest way to get around. For the second problem, there are objects in the worlds that you can pick up, move around and then teleport on to so that you can spray higher up. Keep an eye out for ladders and barrels and such. You teleport or walk up to them, put your hand into them and then use the grab buttons on the controllers to pick them up (the button that is under your middle or ring finger on the controller). To teleport on to the objects just aim the teleport laser at them until you see the circle appear on top and let go. Not sure about the turntable height. If you also feel a little too close to the ground when in the levels, it may be that your floor height isn't set properly (that'll be in the oculus settings). If you're able to, join up to the discord: https://discord.gg/Yc2B5av . We're on there along with lots of very helpful people. We can help you out a little better if we can have a two-way conversation :) If not, you can send an email via our contact page (http://infectiousape.com/contact/) and we can help you through there. If neither of those communication methods work for you, hop in to multiplayer mode and join a session with someone and they should be able to show you in person how to navigate the levels.

itschriscollinsOct 19 at 3:46 AM
Great but missing QoL

So, first off a tip: press Y to see all the controls, and you can pick up objects like ladders in some levels and stand on them to reach higher.

Now, four stars because it's a good game but. Cans feel great, paint system is good, very satisfying. Lots of caps and clever menu choices. But there's a lot of quality of life missing and the developer communication is really lacking on the PC version and this release.

Not all levels have something you can climb. One has a ladder but one has nothing, so if you're under 6" or can only sit down then you're going to be limited in what you can spray. Some levels have objects like crates that you can pick up but you can't stand on them - why the hell not? There's no indication on the controls or guidance at all which could've been easily fixed by just saying "Press Y to see the controls". The developers put in a cool control map and then never tell people how to use it. There's no undo - now this is very realistic but I didn't buy a virtual reality headset and a game to be super realistic, I expect some convenience. The developer has said it isn't possible because of how they handle textures, unlike say Tilt Brush, but there's a PCVR app ViveSpray2 that does spray painting and undo just fine.

This is a finished app. It works great. I'll recommend it. But beware it's missing QoL features and the developer communication is bad. Period. Hopefully once the dust settles I can update this review.

Developer ResponseNov 6 at 2:59 AM

Thanks for the feedback. Regarding point 1, we've been thinking about implementing an "Advanced" mode for the people that want a much more true to life experience where the cans lose pressure and need to be shaken to keep the spray smooth and eventually run out and you have a limited supply of paint or things to that effect. So perhaps you'd choose one milk crate full of cans before you start a piece and lock in colours and all that and then that's all you have to work with (having a "used can" counter or maybe even a "litres of paint" counter could work as well). It's good to know that there are people who want that more realistic experience (who want more of a graffiti simulation than a regular paint program). But there are also a lot of people who are trying to learn and want to be able to hone their style without having to deal with the hassles of using real paint. That is why we'd probably lean towards having an "advanced mode"; so people can choose a simpler or more advanced experience as they want. For point 2, I totally agree about the drips. Originally the drips were much more realistic (the paint was much more drippy when up close) but beta testers preferred having it less drippy so we scaled it back. Perhaps we can put in a slider for drippiness so people can get the feel that they prefer. I'll play around with that when we do our first feature update. It's nice to know that someone else likes the drips, too :) For point 3, performance is a limiting factor on the quest for many of the features that we'd like to implement (we had to scale things back quite a bit compared to the PC version). We have a prototype that does exactly what you are asking for that we may be sneaking in to the PC build on the next update. If that goes well I'll see if we can get at least one level working like that on the quest (you're not the first person to ask about that)... but again, it all comes down to performance. If we can't get the performance right on the quest, it doesn't make it in. If you're able to, join up to the discord (https://discord.gg/Yc2B5av). It'd be nice to get some more conversation happening about some of these things.

tully.travellerOct 21 at 10:58 AM
The smell of paint is missing... but...

From the moment you set foot on the rooftop (or underpass, or subway station) you can feel that this is a special title. The graphics and lighting are great with many small details in over six different environments. The sound of the spray can when you shake it and the vast array of colours and metallics available leaves a wonderfully open palette for creativity. Spraying too long on one spot can cause the paint to drip, further deepening the experience and really making you feel as though you're actually spraying. Selecting some music to play on your "Boombox" made two hours of 'gaming' slip away and I only left Kingspray then because the battery expired.
So why only 3 stars for such a brilliant execution of grafitti spraying in VR? In real life, once you've sprayed, there's no 'undo'. Unfortunately, they've also omitted an 'undo' feature in VR. And while there is a good assortment of locations, you can only paint on certain surfaces within these environments. The ability to mask or stencil is also lacking and I found it difficult to "share" my work to show it off to non-VR users. Being able to play your own music would also be a nice feature. The "replay system", "director system" and projector feature mentioned on the website are noticably missing from the Quest version.
This, I believe, is a must-have application for Quest owners, even if you're not artistically inclined. It's just too bad there are these noticable omissions in the features of this otherwise brilliant execution of VR grafitti.
